awd_titl_txt: Long Term Regularity of Solutions of Fluid Models
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project studies a class of partial differential equations that describe physical phenomena including water waves, plasmas, and gravitation.  The complicated nature of the solutions to such equations often precludes complete mathematical analysis, and applications rely on numerical approximations.  This project studies the solutions of these equations rigorously and recovers quantitative and qualitative information about their behavior as mathematical theorems. The project involves graduate students and postdoctoral associates in the research and fosters collaborations with researchers in related fields, including physics and engineering. 

This project studies the solutions of several quasilinear dispersive partial differential equations, including water-wave models in two and three spatial dimensions, the more general case of two-fluid interfaces, and the Einstein-Klein-Gordon equations of general relativity. The main problems under study concern the global stability of the equilibrium solutions of these equations and the construction of solutions that become singular in finite time. The project aims to contribute new methods and tools to this dynamic field.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This NSF grant had two equally important components. On the scientific side we focused on several problems concerning the long-term dynamics of solutions of certain important evolution equations. On the broader impact side the PI continued collaborations with several researchers at other mathematical centers in the US, and mentored several young students and postdoctoral researchers.

 

The main scientific results of the PIs concern global stability theorems in General Relativity (stability and precise asymptotic analysis of the Einstein-Klein-Gordon coupled system) and Fluid Dynamics (stability of certain shear flows and vortices for the 2D Euler equations and long-term regularity of water waves). These results represent important steps in our understanding of the dynamics of solutions of certain physical evolution equations. For example, stability of stationary solutions of the Euler equations, such as shear flows and vortices, is one of the most important problems in Hydrodynamics, with a long history going back to the 19th century, which is only now becoming well-understood at the nonlinear level.

 

These mathematical problems are very rich and suitable for learning and partial progress. Many of the research results were disseminated widely in national and international conferences by PI; some of these results were also integrated smoothly as part of advanced graduate courses at Princeton University. A crucial component of the grant was to support the training of three graduate students at Princeton University (F. Zheng, X. Ma, and K. Jin) and four postdoctoral fellows (F. Pusateri, J. Gomez-Serrano, S. Iyer, and H. Jia).

 

The project fostered collaborations and increased interactions among researchers at several leading universities in the US. These exchanges had a training component as well, involving lectures accessible to graduate students and postdocs to disseminate current ideas and progress.


Last Modified: 10/24/2021
Modified by: Alexandru D Ionescu
